plot_histogram.py - create line plot of tabular data¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

Reads data in tabular format with observations in rows in different samples in columns. The first column provides the bins.

Missing values (na) are ignored.

Reads data from stdin unless infile is given.

Usage¶

Example:

python plot_histogram.py --help

Type:

python plot_histogram.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: plot_histogram.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  -l LEGEND, --legend=LEGEND
                        legend for plot [default=none].
  -t TITLE, --title=TITLE
                        title for plot [default=none].
  -p FILE, --hardcopy=FILE
                        filename for hardcopy of plot. The extension defines
                        the format. Known extensions are: 'emf, eps, jpeg,
                        jpg, pdf, png, ps, raw, rgba, svg, svgz'
                        [default=none].
  --xrange=XRANGE       x viewing range of plot [default=none].
  --yrange=YRANGE       y viewing range of plot[default=none].
  -o LOGSCALE, --logscale=LOGSCALE
                        use logscale on x, y or xy [default=none]
  -x XTITLE, --xtitle=XTITLE
                        title for x axis [default=none]
  -y YTITLE, --ytitle=YTITLE
                        title for y axis [default=none]
  -d DPI, --dpi=DPI     dpi of images [default=80]
  -n, --normalize       normalize histograms [default=none]
  --cumulate            calculate cumulative histogram [default=False].
  --reverse-cumulate    calculate cumulative histogram in reverse order
                        [default=False].
  --legend-location=LEGEND_LOCATION
                        location of legend [default=upper right]
  --backend=BACKEND     backend to use [Agg|SVG|PS] [default=cairo]
  --symbols=SYMBOLS     symbols to use for each histogram [steps|...] [default
                        =g-D,b-h,r-+,c-+,m-+,y-+,k-o,g-^,b-<,r->,c-D,m-h].
  --dump                dump data for debug purposes [default=False].
  -c COLUMNS, --columns=COLUMNS
                        columns to use for plotting [default=all].
  --truncate            truncate date within x range. If not set, xrange is
                        simply a viewing range [default=False].
  --as-lines            plot only lines, no symbols [default=False].
  --noheaders           do not take first input line as header [default=True].
  --stacked             do a stacked plot [default=False].
  --add-function=FUNCTION
                        add a function to the plot [default=none].
  --add-error-bars=ERROR_BARS
                        add error bars. The input format is 'interleaved' or
                        'blocked'. In the interleaved format the error follows
                        each column. I the blocked format first the data, then
                        the errors in the same order [default=none].
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
